content: What does 'stopped working' mean? Is it not loading? Is it giving any error messages? Can you not access emails already in TB? Can it connect to the email server? Please explain what TB isn't doing.
creator: frisée

content:
Thunderbird isn't an email account but a piece of software used to manage an account. To change your username, you would need to contact your Email provider. There may also be a setting in 'dodgyname@gmail.com' that will forward all your email to another Email account - in which case you would need to make another Gmail account and, eventually, get TB to access this account for email retrieval.

Or why not delete 'dodgyname@gmail.com' and make a single new Gmail account?
creator: frisée

content: When you say 'quit working', what does that actually mean? Does it fail to load? Please send screenshots of any error messages you are getting. Was TB working (downloading email etc.,) when your computer suffered a Communications outage?
creator: frisée

content: I cannot definitively provide you with a solution. I have often had this error and have waited for my ISP to get their act together as it has always been a problem with the SMTP server. Have you contacted your Email Provider or ISP? However, I've accessed your error message by searching in the window at the top left of this screen and note that many have advised that there could be a change in any Third Party anti-virus software that's being used.

If you have kept your emails synced on your Email Server then TB should download them when you establish a new IMAP account.

If you had moved the emails to Local Folders and removed them from the Email Server then it's unlikely that they will able to be recovered.

creator: frisée

content: I'm not sure what you think is wrong. Compacting occurs across all the folders in TB, not just Trash and Junk. When an email is moved from one folder to another, it leaves behind blank space that cumulatively adds up. Compacting removes all this 'space'. If you click on the 3 dots to the right of +New Message and select 'Show Folder Size', you will be able to see the size of each data file relating to the folder. As you move files away from these, the size doesn't reduce because it crates 'blank space'. Compacting removes this.
creator: frisée

content: frisée, thanks for your response. It is possible that I don't really understand the situation, but this is totally different that TB has acted for me in the past. Whenever I have emptied the Trash it has always taken a few moments to accomplish that. Then when I select Compact, it will take a few moments and show me the space recovered. Then when I go to the In Box and select Compact it takes a long time to work its way through my large file. So the recent behavior of instant emptying of Trash and no compaction, but getting compaction from my small Junk folder, does not make sense to me. Thanks.
creator: russg2

content:
I advised you about how to show the space being used on your HD by each of the folders. If you do this, you will see how much space is being used and whether it seems to be disproportionate to the emails contained.

If the space is not shown, it's 'zero'.

If you then compact a folder, you would see a size reduction *if* there is blank space to remove.

Perhaps make some blank space in one of the suspect folders and then see what happens when you compact it?

creator: gfbartlett806

content:
You do realize that the Thunderbird email client is 100% free to download, install and use? as you can even download the source and build it yourself as some Linux users may do.

Mozilla does not even have any form of free one on one direct support by phone, chat, email, ticket etc for their main Firefox web browser products. It would require a lot of resources and call centre places to provide such support even if only in North America and not globally. It is generally the paid for or subscription based applications (like some antivirus clients as an example) that may have some form of direct one on one support because you got that as part of paying for it.

Mozilla did short experiments with third-party direct support for desktop Firefox in the early days by email and by phone though they were paid for and not free

However Mozilla does have direct ticket support for their subscription based products like Mozilla VPN and the premium/plus versions of Firefox Relay, Mozilla Monitor, Pocket, MDN Plus as you get such support as part of the subscription.

All I can suggest is that:

1. You back up all your profiles. C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release

2. You re-install the same version WITHOUT UNINSTALLING to see if it might overwrite a corrupted line of code. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/

Please respond to this - even if you don't want to do this - so that your email re-enters the list of questions that need answering.

creator: kawczynski.insidepark

content:
In future, make back ups weekly. It saves a lot of heartache when systems crash.

In Windows, your profiles and data files are at C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release

For TB to have kept an old copy of your files, it would need to have been made in 'Profiles' (there is a .default' folder but this isn't a previous Profile). My guess is that there might be a third folder in here with your old data.

If it's not, please reply to this and your email will go back in the queue for someone else to look at.

content:
This is a help file that was put together for use with people having problems sending emails. There is a link to a file for receiving them: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-send-messages That will give you some items to check.

My own - limited - experience with Server Timeouts is that they generally resolve themselves and that the problem is with the server rather than the Email program being used.

Please respond to this message if you cannot resolve it and it will get pushed back into the queue of questions to be dealt with.

.oOo.

Dies ist eine Hilfedatei, die für Benutzer zusammengestellt wurde, die Probleme beim Senden von E-Mails haben. Es gibt einen Link zu einer Datei zum Empfangen von E-Mails: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-send-messages Dort finden Sie einige Punkte, die Sie überprüfen sollten.

Meine eigene – begrenzte – Erfahrung mit Server-Timeouts ist, dass sie sich im Allgemeinen von selbst lösen und dass das Problem eher beim Server als beim verwendeten E-Mail-Programm liegt.

Bitte antworten Sie auf diese Nachricht, wenn Sie das Problem nicht lösen können. Sie wird dann wieder in die Warteschlange der zu bearbeitenden Fragen verschoben.

Prova a fare queste operazioni di manutenzione:

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]

content:
I used to get this when my ISP was blacklisted by some Mail Providers. It appeared that someone was sending out large amounts of Spam through the Email Provider and we all got blocked.

You could start by contacting the recipient to see if there's something they can do with their Email provider. You could also reboot your PC to obtain a new IP address for your connection.

You could also look at your email to see if there is anything in it that might be identified as spam. Such as the use of many recipients under Bcc and Cc fields (I presently get emails rejected if I Bcc too many people).

creator: markh2

content:
I share your frustration and I have complained since 2022 when threading became the default. Have you changed the default in config editor? That's the best defense we have.

To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0 =unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

FOR EXISTING FOLDERS These steps may help: To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: This must be done on an account by account basis.

  1. select table view - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane
  2. select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key)
  3. click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane
  4. select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...'
  5. highlight 'folder and children'
  6. move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.

content: Ja, Mark Heijl, uiteraard, mijn vraag ging expliciet over de SMTP-instellingen. Daar is echter geen plek voor het wachtwoord. Op andere computers krijg ik van Thunderbird bij zenden een bericht dat het wachtwoord niet klopt en dat ik het daar kan invullen, en eventueel ook laten opslaan. Op deze computer krijg ik bij zenden alleen het bericht dat er niet geauthentiseerd kan worden. Zonder enige aanwijzing voor het oplossen van het probleem. Daarom was ik aan het zoeken op alle plekken waar serverinstellingen bereikbaar zijn. Zonder resultaat. Toevallig kreeg ik vandaag eindelijk van Thunderbird de mogelijkheid om het wachtwoord in te voeren bij zenden. Het probleem is dus opgelost. Het blijft mij een raadsel waarom het tot gisteren niet lukte, en hoe het komt dat Thunderbird zich vandaag wel correct gedroeg.

content: Troppo tempo fa, quest'estate. A questo punto sono riuscito a ripulire la cartella, spostando tutto in altre cartelle riducendo le perdite al tollerabile: mi è rimasta solo una mail che non si cancella in alcun modo, rallenta se provo a leggerla o cancellarla e sembra la causa dei problemi (due allarmi: uno che segnala problemi con gli account, l'altro che mi dice che la cartella non può essere scritta, che compaiono a ogni apertura del programma). Mi basterebbe che il programma riprendesse a funzionare regolarmente e la soluzione sembrerebbe la sostituzione della cartella Posta in Arrivo (di Cartelle Locali, ne ho altre tre relative ad altri account): è possibile?
creator: neri.pollastri

content:
Si è possibile, ma prima fai un backup completo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

Poi, da Windows, apri la cartella del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_come-trovare-il-proprio-profilo apri al suo interno la casella chiamata Mail e poi la cartella LocalFoder

al suo interno dovresti trovare un file senza estensione chiamato Inbox ed uno chiamato Inbox.msf

Eliminandoli dovresti eliminare la cartella Posta in arrivo. Puoi anche in alternativa provare ad aprirli con un editor di testo ed eliminare tutto il contenuto.

Fai tutto con Thunderbird chiuso.
creator: @next

content: Nell'effettuare il backup del profilo il file Inbox risulta non leggibile; anche copiato da solo, poco oltre metà si blocca. Ho quindi copiato tutto il profilo, escluso Inbox
creator: neri.pollastri

content: Bisognerebbe capire perché è bloccato. Potrebbe ad esempio essere sintomo di un danno al filesystem o al drive. Forse un controllo con un software SMART potrebbe essere utile (tipo CrystalDiskInfo)
creator: @next

content: Proverò a verificare, anche perché si tratta dell'hard disk del PC, anche se non è la partizione di sistema. Nel frattempo ho spostato ogni cartella tra gli archivi (avevo una sottocartella per ogni annualità sotto Posta in Arrivo), ho rinominato con estensione txt Inbox e Inbox.msf, e la cartella Posta in Arrivo che si è creata adesso pare funzionare. Da notare che il vecchio Inbox, quello corrotto, che in teoria non dovrebbe contenere più niente, è invece un file di 1,6 Gb! Grazie comunque, mi è stato di grande aiuto!

Hello, frisée,

Thank you for your interest and reply.

My three email accounts are all POP/SMTP ones. Following your suggestion, I first right-clicked my Junk folder heading, but did not find a repair option. My tree is collapsed to show only Unified Folders, so I expanded Junk, right-clicked each of the three email accounts, and sequentially ran the repair routine(s), which completed satisfactorily. This made no change in that delay for anything to happen once Junk (Unified) is right-clicked, but the delay time is now a consistent 5 seconds, which certainly is tolerable, though baffling. Moreover, I now see emails in the Junk folder and am able to delete them in the usual manner, not just doing a Ctrl+A and Delete.

So at this point I'm satisfied, yet still mystefied. In answer to your question, I do feel sufficiently structure-savvy to navigate to anything under C:\, though would need to be told what to do once I land there.

No, Inbox and Sent folders are just fine, my only concern was that, doubtless stored in the same Windows area as Junk, an inadvertent misstep could turn them to toast. But I can be careful.

As for the Junk, it seems only Unified Junk is subject to the right-click 5-second delay before the drop-down options menu opens. If I have the tree expanded and right-click any one of the three email Junk folders, it presents the options menu immediately.

Again, although this delay action I'm seeing is quite new, now that it's only 5 seconds it's certainly not a show-stopper... I could certainly live with it, but in the interest of finding or understanding any sort of bug in Thunderbird, I'd be happy to help.
creator: Electrojim

content:
I always take some precautions so, although you may think some of these points are irrelevant, please don't miss any out.

This will work with the Junk Folder because it's a system folder. But there are always implications with doing this procedure with other folders so this is the only one that I know it will work with - that's because I've done this myself before sending you the below procedure.

1. Close Thunderbird.

2. Close all other open programs (I always do this to make sure nothing interacts with the program I'm working on).

3. Make a Folder on your Desktop. Call it what you will.

4. Open: C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release

5. As we are going to be deleting a Thunderbird System Folder in a POP account, access the 'Mail Folder'.

6. There are folders in here that relate to each of your POP3 accounts and also to your Local Folders. Open the folder that relates to the account under which you are having the problem with the Junk Folder.

7. There are two folders named 'Junk'. One is just 'Junk' and the other is 'Junk.msf'. MOVE - do not delete - both these files into the Folder that you made on your Desktop.

8. Keep this folder open.

9. Launch Thunderbird.

10. The POP3 account that we've just deleted the Junk Folder from will no longer have a Junk Folder (probably). Click on the root of this POP3 account and a new Junk Folder will be created. I've done this so that, if there was an irreparable corruption, we're starting from something that is clean.

11. Check the folder you have kept open and two new Junk files will have been made. Close the folder.

12. Run this for a while and see if it has made a difference. Also keep the files for a couple of days that you removed in case there are implications that might need you reinstalling them.

I would be grateful if you would post a response here to tell me if this has resolved your problem. This is for my info so I know I can use it again for other people with the same problem.
creator: frisée

content:
Okay, I can probably do that. I will have to wait until the close of the 'business day,' however, as I use email a lot during awake hours. I do have two questions, however.

It is ONLY when I right-click the Unified Junk folder that the delay occurs. Should I perform your procedure on each of the accounts separately and independently?
  2. When you say, "Click on the root of this POP3 account..." I'm not quite sure what you mean. Can you give me an example, maybe a screenshot of a typical Tbird install showing the 'root'?

Again, many thanks.

content:

I do not have technical experience with Unified Folders so I would refrain from performing the fix.

2. In the hierarchy, it will be at the top. It will be what you called the account.

If you have more than one Junk Folder performing irregularly, then it's unlikely that it is a corrupted file. I can't find anywhere that you said that it was ALL Junk folders. I was offering a solution as I thought you had trouble with a single folder that was inside a single account.

content:
I located this info - so check it out to see if Pop is enabled.

1. Sign in to your Juno Email on the Web at webmail.juno.com 2. Click on "Options" and select "General," or click on "Settings" and select "POP Mail" under "Preferences" 3. Select "ON - POP my mail to my desktop/smartphone" 4. Click "Save" to finish

I also found this: http://help.juno.com/support/webmail/jn/webmail-error-no-auth.html?sbrand=JN

Also Check this: Exit Thunderbird Access Firewall - this might be the default that came with computer OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program.

creator: ledmyszkow

content:
Led Myszków said
Now all my emails older than 1 year are gone and I have to figure out how to bring them back :/. At leats from last 5 years.

I just tested in my POP account > Properties > Retention Policy by setting "Delete messages more 10 days old" and when those messages had been deleted after restart I opened the Inbox file in a text editor. I could identify the deleted messages since they were still present in the file but with a X-Mozilla Status : 0009 which means "message is deleted". To recover those deleted messages one must first avoid to compact the Inbox folder. Then by changing the X-Mozilla Status from 0009 to 0001 those "deleted" messages will again be displayed in the Inbox folder. after TB restart. Probably you would also have to "rebuild" the folder.

content: I don't understand how that applies. Gmail accounts all use the same outgoing server information with the exception of the user name.
creator: rdbrown58

content: You must have as many smtp servers as you have accounts: smtp1, smtp2, ...., all with the same settings - smtp.gmail.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 - except different User Names (email address). Then, point account1 to smtp1, account2 to smtp2,..., as explained in the link in my first reply. Remove the entries from Saved Passwords in Settings, restart TB, enter the account password for each account in the OAuth2 window.
